Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Behavioral and Computational Investigation of Transitivity in the Acquisition of Non-Basic Syntax

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Within the first years of life and without explicit instruction, children acquire a linguistic system that allows them to combine sounds in order to express meanings. Studying this process illuminates how a cognitive system as complicated as language can develop in the human mind, and helps clarify the nature of learning in development. Learning in general requires building on prior knowledge: children can't learn arithmetic if they don't know how to count. This project asks how infants build on their prior linguistic knowledge at each stage of their development, using the limited amount of speech they are able to understand, in order to learn more about the structure of their language. By improving our understanding of how infants learn about their language at each stage in development, the project provides an important step toward understanding why and how the quantity and type of speech heard in infancy contribute to differences in children's later vocabulary and language performance, in school and later in life.

This research focuses on the acquisition of "non-basic" clauses as a window into the incremental nature of language learning. Sentences like "What did Mary fix?" are potentially misleading for children in the earliest stages of syntax acquisition, who might not recognize that "what" stands for the object of "fix" and might think that this clause is intransitive. This work pursues the hypothesis that children may use knowledge about verb argument structure in order to identify non-basic clause types in their language. The research integrates approaches from different research communities, using behavioral experiments to investigate the developmental trajectory of non-basic clause acquisition, and computational modelling to evaluate whether the proposed mechanisms are feasible for learning from child-directed speech. Through this case study, this research aims to provide a fuller picture of what portion of the input is useful to an individual child at any single point in development, how children perceive that input given their current grammatical knowledge, and what internal mechanisms enable them to generalize beyond that input in inferring the grammar of their language. The project also includes outreach about issues in language development to local families and high school students from under-represented backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how infants begin to represent the syntax of "non-basic" clauses, which do not follow the canonical word order of the language. For example, an English learner who hears What are you holding? must identify that what acts as the object of hold at a distance. Because different non-basic clause types take different shapes across languages, learners must identify the specific forms they take in the language they are exposed to. We ask what combination of existing linguistic knowledge and mechanisms for learning from data enable them to do this. The acquisition of non-basic syntax provides a window into how language acquisition unfolds incrementally in development, giving us insight into how children represent and learn from their linguistic input at any given developmental stage.

The behavioral component of this project showed that infants representations of wh-questions develop during the second year of life. We found that 18-month-olds represent a fronted wh-phrase (e.g. what) as a non-local object of a verb, but younger infants do not: 15-month-olds responded only when a required object of a verb was locally present or missing. In the computational component of this project, we investigated the learning mechanisms responsible for this development. We found that it is in principle possible for a learner to use the surface property distributions of sentences in child-directed speech in order to identify the forms that various non-basic clause types take in English. Moreover, doing so incrementally requires building on prior knowledge of which verbs need objects. This provides a computational account for the developmental trajectory we observe empirically: infants might use knowledge of basic verb argument structure-- how verbs typically occur with local subjects and objects-- in order to identify when arguments have been moved.

The case study in this project speaks to the broader question of how learners leverage their developing linguistic knowledge in order to represent their linguistic input, and how they learn from those developing input representations. This work has novel implications for linguistic theory by showing one way in which we can incorporate development into a model of language acquisition. It has further implications for our theories of learning in any domain, by deepening our understanding of how learners generalize from noisy or incomplete representations of data. In addition, the behavioral and computational methods developed in this project provide new ways for the field to study the earliest stages of syntactic development in infancy, with implications for understanding how input differences early in childhood affect later language development and performance in school and in life. This project contributed to cross-disciplinary discussion among linguists, developmental psychologists, and computational cognitive scientists through four conference presentations. In addition to supporting a doctoral dissertation, it provided three undergraduate students with in-depth research experience and training outside of their home disciplines. It was featured in outreach efforts to the local community, building awareness of research in linguistics and cognitive development.
